solutions.title: mathematical-explanation
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
This can be solved by using mathematical deduction. By looking at the input and output of example 1 we have a concrete idea of where we are starting and where we need to end up. This allows us to more easily come up with an equation.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
First we need to convert the given description to a math formula. 

We want to know how many steps it takes to get from "x" to "num" so we can subtract the two $$(x - num)$$.

Next we have simultaneous operations of increment/decrement "x" and "num" that is performed each operation. Everytime "x" changes "num" also has to change; we are doing two steps for every single operation. Therefore we only need half the steps of $$(x - num)$$ in order for "x" to equal "num". Which gives us $$(x-num)/2$$ amount of steps.

The number of steps allowed needs to be "t" so then we have the equation $$t = (x-num)/2$$.

In the problem we are given "t" and "num" so we solve for x, yielding the equation $$x = 2t + num$$ which can be written as code to retun the "x" value required by the problem.


# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$ - We perform a constant mathematical statement

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$ - No new memory required
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def theMaximumAchievableX(self, num: int, t: int) -> int:
        return 2 * t + num
```

title: Visit Array Positions to Maximize Score
question_content:
You are given a 0-indexed integer array nums and a positive integer x.

You are initially at position 0 in the array and you can visit other positions according to the following rules:

  • If you are currently in position i, then you can move to any position j such that i < j.
  • For each position i that you visit, you get a score of nums[i].
  • If you move from a position i to a position j and the parities of nums[i] and nums[j] differ, then you lose a score of x.

Return the maximum total score you can get.

Note that initially you have nums[0] points.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [2,3,6,1,9,2], x = 5
Output: 13
Explanation: We can visit the following positions in the array: 0 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4.
The corresponding values are 2, 6, 1 and 9. Since the integers 6 and 1 have different parities, the move 2 -> 3 will make you lose a score of x = 5.
The total score will be: 2 + 6 + 1 + 9 - 5 = 13.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [2,4,6,8], x = 3
Output: 20
Explanation: All the integers in the array have the same parities, so we can visit all of them without losing any score.
The total score is: 2 + 4 + 6 + 8 = 20.

 

Constraints:

  • 2 <= nums.length <= 105
  • 1 <= nums[i], x <= 106

solutions.content:
![image.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/831f7286-b669-4bd2-b529-10c52725d299_1690602680.2222533.png)


# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        dp = [0] * (length:=len(nums))
        dp[0] = nums[0]

        even = nums[0] if (nums[0] % 2 == 0) else -inf
        odd = nums[0] if (nums[0] % 2 != 0) else -inf

        for right in range(1,length):
            if (cur:=nums[right]) %2 == 0:
                dp[right] = max(even,odd-x)+cur
                even = dp[right]
            else:
                dp[right] = max(even-x,odd)+cur
                odd = dp[right]

        return max(odd,even)
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
greedily look at last even and last odd number's index, they will yield the highest result

# Approach
prefix sum, keeping track of last odd and last even index

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(n)

- Space complexity:
O(n)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        N = len(nums)
        pref = [0] * N

        pref[0] = nums[0]

        lastEven = 0
        lastOdd = 0

       


        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            
            pref[i] = pref[lastEven] + nums[i] - (((nums[lastEven] + nums[i]) % 2) * x)

            pref[i] = max(pref[i], pref[lastOdd] + nums[i] - (((nums[lastOdd] + nums[i]) % 2) * x))


            if nums[i] % 2:
                lastOdd = i

            else:
                lastEven = i

        return max(pref)



        
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Dp, always track max even ended and max odd ended
# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(1)$$
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        
        max_odd,max_even=nums[0]-x*(1-nums[0]%2),nums[0]-x*(nums[0]%2)
        res=nums[0]
        
        for i in range(1,len(nums)):
            num=nums[i]
            if num%2:
                max_odd=max(max_odd+num,max_even+num-x)        
            else:
                max_even=max(max_even+num,max_odd+num-x)
            res=max(res,max_odd,max_even)
       
        return res
        
        
```

python-3-dp-binary-search-greedy
solutions.content:
# Intuition
You need dp because obviously there is only 1 state variable. But the question is how to do dp iteration effective.

If you study the statement carefully, you know that for each step, you have 2 choices: next odd num, or next even num. Just these 2. So you don't need to do extra loop. This is greedy. To find next odd/even num effectively, use binary search.

# Approach
dp + bs + greedy

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
O(nlogn) -> n for state variable. In every dp iteration, I do bs which costs O(logn)

- Space complexity:
O(n) -> cache size

# Code
```
import bisect

class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:

        # parity: True = odd
        parity2ind = collections.defaultdict(list)

        for ind, num in enumerate(nums):
            parity = nums[ind] % 2 == 1
            parity2ind[parity].append(ind)

        @cache
        def dp(i): # return int, max score?
            # parity: True = odd
            if i == nums:
                return 0

            this_parity = nums[i] % 2 == 1

            take_oddi = bisect.bisect_left(parity2ind[True], i + 1)
            if take_oddi < len(parity2ind[True]):
                final_oddi = parity2ind[True][take_oddi]
                odd = dp(final_oddi)
                if this_parity != True: # diff parity
                    odd -= x
            else:
                odd = 0
            
            take_eveni = bisect.bisect_left(parity2ind[False], i + 1)
            if take_eveni < len(parity2ind[False]):
                final_eveni = parity2ind[False][take_eveni]
                even = dp(final_eveni)
                if this_parity != False:
                    even -= x
            else:
                even = 0
            
            return max(odd, even) + nums[i]

        return dp(0)




```

solutions.content:
# Intuition

DP

# Approach

Track the maximum odd and even scores

# Complexity

- Time complexity: $$O(n)$$

- Space complexity: $$O(1)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        n = len(nums)
        max_odd = nums[0] if nums[0] % 2 else float('-inf')
        max_even = nums[0] if nums[0] % 2 == 0 else float('-inf')
        for i in range(1, n):
            if nums[i] % 2:
                max_odd = max(max_even + nums[i] - x, max_odd + nums[i])
            else:
                max_even = max(max_odd + nums[i] - x, max_even + nums[i])
        return max(max_odd, max_even)

```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
This is traditional 1D dynamic array porblems. With the constraint at 10^5 it is clear that only solution with O(n) will works.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
From any point in an array you can only move forward and thus, all the callculation happened before hand becomes constaint. Keeping in mind that, we take 2 variables to track maximum answer obtained till that point, and update itteratively.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
O(n)

- Space complexity:
0(1)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums, x):
        odd = 0
        even = 0
        if nums[0]%2==0:
            even = nums[0]
            odd = nums[0]-x
        else:
            odd = nums[0]
            even = nums[0]-x
        
        for i in nums[1:]:
            if i%2==0:
                a = i+even
                b = i+odd-x
                even = max(a,b)
            else:
                a  = i+ even -x
                b = i+ odd
                odd = max(a,b)
        return max(odd,even)
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
1. Observe that once a number is selected, any consecutive numbers with the same parity can be added to the total.

2. We can easily just add all consecutive numbers together into a new array. 
Example:
[2,3,6,1,9,2] => [2,3,6,10,2]

3. This new array (let's call it `arr`) has the following properties:
a. `arr[i]` and `arr[i+1]` will always have different parities (as they are the sum of all consequtive numbers in `nums` with the same parity). 
b. If we wish to include index `arr[i+1]` in the `total`, we must always deduct `x` from it, while `arr[i+2]` could simply be added to the current `total`. 

4. Now we can work on the solution by defining a  `recurse` function. The `total` will be `arr[i]` + the maximum of:
a. `recurse(i+1) - x`
b. `recurse(i+2)`

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(N)
- Space complexity: O(N)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        def recurse(i):
            if i >= len(arr):
                return 0
            if dp[i] > 0:
                return dp[i]
            dp[i] = arr[i] + max(recurse(i+1) - x, recurse(i+2))
            return dp[i]

        arr = [nums[0]]
        parity = nums[0] % 2
        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            if nums[i] % 2 == parity:
                arr[-1] += nums[i]
            else:
                parity = nums[i] % 2
                arr.append(nums[i])

        dp = [0 for i in range(len(arr))]
        return recurse(0)
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int:
        '''
        [2,3,6,1,9,2], x = 5
        
        [2 ,0,0,0,0,0]
        [-3,0,0,0,0,0]
        
        [2 ,2,0,0,0,0]
        [-3,0,0,0,0,0]
        
        [2 ,2,8,0,0,0]
        [-3,0,0,0,0,0]
        
        [2 ,2,8,8,0,0]
        [-3,0,0,4,0,0]
        
        [2 ,2,8,8,8, 0]
        [-3,0,0,4,13,0]
        
        [2 ,2,8,8,8, 10]
        [-3,0,0,4,13,13]
        
        '''
        n = len(nums)
        even = [0]*n
        odd = [0]*n
        even[0] = odd[0] = nums[0]
        
        if nums[0]%2 == 0: odd[0] -= x
        else: even[0] -= x
        
        for i in range(1,n):
            if nums[i]%2 == 0:
                even[i] = max( even[i-1]+nums[i], odd[i-1]+nums[i]-x)
                odd[i] = odd[i-1]
            else:
                even[i] = even[i-1]
                odd[i] = max( even[i-1]+nums[i]-x, odd[i-1]+nums[i])
        return max(even[-1], odd[-1])
       
            
        
```

solutions.content:
Disclaimer ChatGPT helped me write the solution post
# Intuition To maximize the total score while visiting positions in the array, we need to make the right decision at each step. When visiting an index `i`, we have two choices for the next index `j` (where `j` > `i`): If the parity of `nums[i]` and `nums[j]` is the same, we can directly add the values of `nums[i]` and `nums[j]` to the total score. If the parity of `nums[i]` and `nums[j]` is different, we should subtract `x` from the total score. If for each visiting index `i` we check for all index `j` >`i` and find a candidate the solution would become an $$O(n^2)$$ rather we can maintain a odd and even max parity sum # Approach We'll maintain two variables, max_par_odd and max_par_even, to keep track of the maximum total scores obtained with the last visited position having odd or even parity, respectively. 1. Initialize `max_par_odd` and `max_par_even` to 0. 2. Iterate over the array from left to right: * Calculate the parity of the current number (`nums[i] % 2`). * If the current number has odd parity: * Update max_par_odd by taking the maximum of (`max_par_odd`, `max_par_even - x + nums[i]`). * If the current number has even parity: * Update `max_par_even` by taking the maximum of (`max_par_even`, `max_par_odd - x + nums[i]`). 3. After the loop, the variable `max(max_par_odd, max_par_even)` will contain the maximum total score that can be obtained. # Complexity - Time complexity: The algorithm iterates through the array once, so the time complexity is $$O(n)$$, where n is the length of the array. - Space complexity: The space complexity is $$O(1)$$ as we are using a constant number of variables to store intermediate results, irrespective of the input size. # Code ``` class Solution: def maxScore(self, nums: List[int], x: int) -> int: max_par1=max_par2=0 dp=[0]*len(nums) ret_max=None for i in range(len(nums)-1,-1,-1): parity = nums[i]%2 if parity: max_par1 = max(max_par1,max_par2-x) + nums[i] ret_max = max_par1 else: max_par2 = max(max_par2,max_par1-x) + nums[i] ret_max = max_par2 return ret_max ```

content.content: I think this problem could use better description, seriously they are using the word `parity` . Anyone in computer science can think  `If the total number of set-bits in the binary representation of a number is even then the number is said to have even parity, otherwise, it will have odd parity.`  But here they simply meant even or odd. I wasted so much time in contest trying to figure out what just parity was, and couldn\'t solve it. It\'s unfair.
I also, thanks\n
I understood after reading your comment!
Agreed! They need to distinguish between mathematical parity (whether an integer is odd or even) and computer science parity ( number of bits that are set to 1).
Thanks, I didn\u2019t understand what they meant by \u201Cparity\u201D before this comment!
WTF is parities.

[@ms232gg](/ms232gg) It basically means that, any two numbers can have same parity if and only if both are either even or both are odd. If either one is even/ odd and other being opposite of it, then we can consider that they have different parities.
243 solutions but no one has answered this yet. People just hungry for upvotes rather than actually helping

They should have defined what a parity means. @leetcode, please take a note of this and resolve the statement. People reviewing this question before this was up for the contest should re-evaluate their reviewing strategies.

This Note section of this question make it easier. 
Think about the case when nums[0] is not selected initially. This might make it tougher than all other question. 
Well my idea for this case is -
Whatever the initial category(even or odd) of number is chosen the final chosen number must be last even number or last odd number. So apply the same solution which is applied on this question but starts from last odd  number occurred index and do same for last even occurred number and return the maximum of two.

Note: Feel free to share your opinion and if I am wrong then provide your approach.

Here is the code link for my above approach. 
[Solution](https://leetcode.com/problems/visit-array-positions-to-maximize-score/submissions/1001023126/)

Mostly because even though you have memoized, for each index you are looping through all the greater indices so in total O(n^2) calls are being made. You arent calculating it n^2 times rather just calling it that many times. Try to fix it by using the standard skip/take method instead of looping through the greater indices for each index

You arent calculating it n^2 times rather just calling it that many times. Try to fix it by using the standard skip/take method instead of looping through the greater indices for each index

I think this problem could use better description, seriously they are using the word `parity` . Anyone in computer science can think  `If the total number of set-bits in the binary representation of a number is even then the number is said to have even parity, otherwise, it will have odd parity.`  But here they simply meant even or odd. I wasted so much time in contest trying to figure out what just parity was, and couldn\'t solve it. It\'s unfair.

I understood after reading your comment!
Agreed! They need to distinguish between mathematical parity (whether an integer is odd or even) and computer science parity ( number of bits that are set to 1).

WTF is parities.

[@ms232gg](/ms232gg) It basically means that, any two numbers can have same parity if and only if both are either even or both are odd. If either one is even/ odd and other being opposite of it, then we can consider that they have different parities.

This Note section of this question make it easier. 
Think about the case when nums[0] is not selected initially. This might make it tougher than all other question. 
Well my idea for this case is -
Whatever the initial category(even or odd) of number is chosen the final chosen number must be last even number or last odd number. So apply the same solution which is applied on this question but starts from last odd  number occurred index and do same for last even occurred number and return the maximum of two.

Note: Feel free to share your opinion and if I am wrong then provide your approach.
